metadata.titleEn: Figures: A new entelodont (Artiodactyla, Mammalia) from the late Eocene of China and its phylogenetic implications
metadata.description: (1) This data includes size comparison images and tables from the original images of a new genus and species of the family Muscidae (Artiodactyla, Mammalia) from the Late Eocene in China, phylogenetic analysis images of the family Muscidae, and geographic and field original images. (2) The main ways to obtain data are through camera field photography and re drawing based on previous research. (3) The image quality is a high-resolution original size image. (4) The prospect of image application is that it can be used for further in-depth research and comparison.
metadata.instructions: Same as the order of the main text chart

Definition.Question: What does 'data collection through camera field photography' mean in the context of paleontological research?
Definition.Answer: Data collection through camera field photography refers to the technique of using cameras to capture high-resolution images of fossils and related field sites. This method allows researchers to document the physical attributes and context of paleontological findings, providing a visual dataset that can be used for further analysis and comparison in studies.

Comparison.Question: How do data collection methods using high-resolution camera field photography compare to those based on re-drawing from previous studies in terms of capturing detailed features of late Eocene Suidae fossils?
Comparison.Answer: Data collection methods using high-resolution camera field photography provide original, high-quality images that capture detailed features directly from the fossil site, offering an accurate representation of the fossils as they are found. In contrast, methods based on re-drawing from previous studies rely on the interpretation and artistic skill of researchers, which might introduce some level of bias or inaccuracy, but can also incorporate insights from prior knowledge and systematic revisions.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the primary objective of collecting high-resolution images and phylogenetic analysis data of new fossil species in the field of Late Eocene artiodactyls in China?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The primary objective is to facilitate further in-depth comparative research on the new fossil species, which includes understanding their phylogenetic significance and geographic distribution.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What methods can be employed to capture high-resolution images of fossil specimens for detailed comparative analysis in paleontological research?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Data collection methods include using cameras for field photography to capture high-resolution original size images of fossil specimens and redrawing images based on previous research.
